title: Meanwhile at Riot:
body:
Somehow every new Champ we introduced is broken OP.

Uh maybe it's because you introduced a heap of new abilities with 0 counterplay?

Darius: mass AOE Champ with heals so you can't focus him down, yet gets massive damage with 5 procs of Hemmorage?
Fiora: Parries everything?
Gankgplank: Puts down 3 Barrels in a triangle between you, him and his CS and can't actually be approached; assuming you are melee or w/e Plus true Damage and armor ignoring barrels along with his cleanse and heal?
Mordekaiser: Just summons a big azz dragon and can't be engaged on heavily even though he needs to be burst down to stop him absorbing massive damage over the duration of a fight?

I mean the counter to all these Champs is just better all ins, more cooldowns or massive damage on a single target so all it makes for is messy fights with no clear outcomes.

Kalista with the absolute dragon control.

I mean all your recent additions that are based on being "unique" just crap on the concept of balance and it's been the same 20 Champs every game in worlds - I hope you; Riot: actually do some game changing nerfs or buffs around the place and not just "faux" nerfs or whatever because it's really disappointing for the competitive community to just be spamming and banning the exact same Champs with no concept of "strategy" in mind and it (the bans) (and their picks) being purely power based with literally no "pre-thought" involved and it being 90% about "strength".

Bringing out a new Champ doesn't make me forget how annoying these ones can be (for me personally) and doesn't make me any less irritated and in fact makes me less likely to fork out dollars for the game and I don't see them being dealt with - most of the time a New champ comes out they in fact aren't OP because these Champ (for me personally) exist and all they do is mix things up - they don't eliminate the weak picks and my interest in the new Champs fades and my annoyance at these (personal) power picks just leaves me more hesitant to buy skins and more hesitant to even play new Champs until I'm sure where their power levels are at and is usually after multiple nerfs or whatever purely for their style; so for a company wanting dollars, leaving a crap load of OP Champs and releasing what are possibly always OP Champs and often nerfing them later is a bad move and also isn't necessary at all in my opinion if you are about the cash - which I don't think Riot are, I just think they're in over their heads and need clear concise statistics and the Worlds provide this - but it also means that if they aren't careful, they'll destroy other aspects of the Champ (for example the nerf to Tank Ekko's jungle affecting his mage side) and if they don't do the balancing in a careful way they could damage the uniquity of the game and I think this is their problem and they also need to look at Solo queue (in fact more so in my opinion) rather than put so much weight on worlds - because the game should be about fun - not professionalism. I don't think E-sports is a good move whatsoever and it seems like that's the way their headed. Many disappointments in LoL's progression.
